thread.title: Things to know for Friday in Pennsylvania
thread.title_full: Things to know for Friday in Pennsylvania

author: The Associated Press
title: Things to know for Friday in Pennsylvania
text:
Things to know for Friday in Pennsylvania By The Associated Press - Associated Press - Friday, October 23, 2015 
A daily look at late-breaking news, coming events and stories that will be talked about in Pennsylvania on Friday. 
ACLU CLAIMS PENNSYLVANIA LETTING MENTALLY ILL DEFENDANTS LANGUISH IN JAIL 
A lawsuit seeking class-action status echoes others already filed in California, Washington and Utah. The lawsuit seeks a court order forcing Pennsylvania to move mentally ill defendants to a state hospital within seven days of a judge’s determination that they are incompetent to stand trial. 
___ 
5 ARRAIGNED ON MURDER CHARGES IN FRAT HAZING DEATH 
The suspects, all from the New York borough of Queens, appeared in a northeastern Pennsylvania courtroom nearly two years after the death of Chun “Michael” Deng. Police say members at Pi Delta Psi abused Deng, who died. Defense lawyers have called the Baruch College student’s death a fraternity prank gone horribly awry. 
___ 
HORSE RACING HELD HOSTAGE? 
Gov. Tom Wolf’s administration says it may suspend horse racing in Pennsylvania in a week because a state budget stalemate has compounded the troubles of a deficit-ridden fund that is supposed to pay for various regulatory functions. 
___ 
ATTORNEY GENERAL KATHLEEN KANE RELEASES EXPLICIT EMAILS TIED TO SUPREME COURT JUSTICE 
The three dozen emails or email exchanges recovered from her agency’s servers - and which she tied to Justice Michael Eakin - were recovered during the course of an unrelated investigation. Eakin has apologized for what he called “insensitive” content in his private email account and says it is out of character for him. 
___ 
PENNSYLVANIA THREATENS TO PULL LICENSE OF IMMIGRATION DETENTION CENTER 
The state Department of Human Services says it won’t renew the Berks County Residential Center’s license if it continues holding immigrant children and adults. The department says the center’s operation as a federal immigration facility is inconsistent with its licensing as a child residential center.
